But you missed the bigger picture: he is producing more maintainable,
less buggy code -- so he spends less time writing production code, but
he's more productive.  I certainly can attest to the experience as
well!  I don't think I spend 70% of my time in testing, but it may be
close.  The problem I have in estimating the amount of time I am writing
test code is that I am constantly switching back and forth between tests
and production.  Tests are more than tests to me, they turn out to be my
design phase as well (as many others will testify of themselves).  So,
how much time do you spend on design?

What would be interesting, and I would be willing to participate, is
given a smallish (but non-trivial) project, let's do an alpha release:
someone try it without TDD (and perhaps without tests -- eeek!!) and I
will do with TDD.  Who gets done in the shortest amount of time?  Who's
code is 'better' (more maintainable, fewer bugs, etc.)?  Who fulfills
all of the requirements?  You get the picture.  I wager that I would
win. ;)

=jason

On Tue, 2003-04-08 at 16:27, javainsel wrote: > Actually, I find that
I'm spending even *larger* amounts of time 
working 
> with my tests.  I haven't measured, but I'd have to guess around 
70%.

If testing time is so high, then who wants to blame me for looking 
for 
Parasoft JTest to make testing more productive?

I know you don't blame me, but others did.

And you understand that DbC is not such a bad idea as some people 
here
believe.
